Be Yourself, Charles!
S. A. C. RULES provide that no activity election is valid unless either the
S. A. C. president or secretary is present.
This implies that the visiting official
knows the rules, is sure of his ground,
is wide awake to all ulterior motives, and
is forceful enough to maintain order. It
was in this role that Squire, as Secretary-Treasurer of the S. A. C., attended
the Band election.
Witness the result: He makes an entirely unfounded ruling to the effect that
proxies are not acceptable by the Council, and thus permits a nominee who was
not elected to take the major office; he
allows the professional director of the
Band to preside at the meeting, a function which belongs exclusively to the
ranking student in the Band. All of
which makes a very unsavory affair of
an otherwise peaceful meeting.
Snap out of it, Charles

valdity of the election, which was held
without allowing him any opportunity to
run for higher position or even to vote.
If the man deserved expulsion he should
not have been allowed to vote and should
not have been reinstated; if, on the contrary, he was without fault, the Council
has done him an injustice in not declaring the election invalid and calling for a
new one. We claim that the Council has
not finished its job.

THE decision of the frosh and sophs
to hold banquets instead of dances during their annual fracas-week is disappointing because it lacks foresight. The
dearth of available funds caused by the
recent ill-famed action of the Union
Trust and the difficulty of persuading reluctant lower-classmen to part with the
price of a banquet are only two of the
present obstacles which will be encountered. And if they go in the hole,—well,
the campus will be too hot for them.
However, even a dance presents some
of these difficulties. But the other side

A treat of an unusual nature is being
offered to Baltimore music lovers at The
Maryland Theatre next week, when The
French-Italian Opera Company, under
the direction of George De Feo, opens
Monday evening for a six-day run.
Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday evenings will witness the performances of
Rigoletto, Faust, and La Bohenze, respectively, while the Wednesday matinee will
be devoted to a presentation of the ever
lovely Barber of Seville.
Lucia de Lamernzoor, Carmen and
Tosca will appear on the last three evenings of the week; the famous twins,
Cavalleria, Rusticana and Pagliacci, being
jointly featured for the matinee on Saturday.
A group of ninety, including a complete
symphony orchestra, a select chorus and
a ballet, comprises this company, the coming of which should prove a real delight
to opera lovers.

IT IS very pleasant to be reminded of
one of the most delightful personalities of
our day, Dr. William H. Welch, who has
now passed his 83-year mark. We are
awed by his tremendous contributions to
medical science, but we are charmed with
his scintillating conversation, his quiet
humor, and his uncanny ability to render
un-self-conscious anyone who has the

us: "During elections it should be remembered that you are voting for men
who will pass judgment on you should you
slip up some time." Whether or not a
man is brought before the Council for
a misdeed which he actually performed
or with which he is merely charged, it is
to his advantage to be'sure that equitable
judgment will be passed. If politics have
elected a man to membership his will is
not his own; he must act at the dictates
of a machine. Such a situation is distinctly unfavorable to anyone who happens to be opposed by the machine.
Roughly fifty percent of the student
body is made up of non-faternity men.
Consequently, there is no reason why they
should allow themselves to be controlled
by the organized other half. The breaks
are all for them because the Council has
set itself to see fair play. If everyone
votes his own mind we can be assured of
an eminently suitable governing body
next year.

Hot Rythm
Marking their first personal appearance
in this city in over five years, Fred Waring and his Pennsylvanians are the feature attraction on the stage of the Hippodrome this week.
Grand Slam, a witty society drama,
starring pretty Loretta Young and the
inimitable Paul Lukas, completes a fine
bill.
Calvalcade Returns
Several weeks ago we wrote in glowing terms of the flowing and dramatic
grandeur of that epic picture—Cavalcade.
To add more would be to subject a great
masterpiece to cheap bally. Sufficient to
say that this stirring picturization of the
history of a mighty empire has returned
for a weeks' engagement at the New.
You really shouldn't miss it.
Tomorrow evening at the Guild Theatre the brilliant Gilbert and Sullivan stage
success, The Gondoliers, will open for a
run which will extend throughout Easter
week.
The Vagabonds, too, should attract the
interest of many during the course of the
next few days. Fresh from the pen of
Donald Kirkley, dramatic critic of The
Sun, the Eastern Shore play, Peace 0fficer, will hold the boards there for the
coming week.
All of which brings up to the end of
this column and one step removed from
a big surprise. It's coming -next week,
and it's coming here. Are you waitin'?

The Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
Of the two copies of the "Life
and Letters of Thomas Henry
Huxley", in two volumes, once
owned by the University, there remains now a single volume, II. On
the (confessedly faint) hope that
my words may come to the attention of the thieves in question and
bring penitence—and restitution—
I make this appeal.
Huxley ought to mean much to
Hopkins men; he presided over the
University's birth; he was grandfather of Julian and Aldous Huxley; he is the idol of Mr. Mencken.
There have been few men capable
in a like degree of inspiring students of literature and of science.
I wish the thieves who stole his
record could suffer the crucifixion
they deserve, but I fear there is
little chance of this.

Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
Dear Sir:
In a current issue, you carry correspondence to the effect that one
Joseph Gore and myself were cast
in dishonor from a Cumberland
dance emporium. This is malicious
gossip.
In the first place, it wasn't a
dance hall. It was a church. In the
second place, the disturbance was
entirely instigated by Mr. Gore,
who attempted to applaud the officiating divine by banging empty
pop bottles against the pews. My
(Continued on Col. 3, Below)

shop, was awarded a national prize
at its premiere in St. Louis is not
apparent perhaps until the curtain
has rung on the second act. Then
in recovering from a violent and
lengthy spasm of guffaws, from
which even a painfully slow execution did not much detract, one is
thoroughly inclined to agree with
the judges, feeling however, that
the Playshop did not make the best
of the opportunities in this hysterical satire.
Primarily because it could not
keep up the allegro tempo in which
the play was written, and secondly
because the actors seemed too much
impressed by the fact that they were
a Napoleon, or a Juliette, to really
allow full play to the burlesque intended, the comedy of the second
act lost in quality.
It made up for this, however, in
cleverness of line and action.
And Birds

All characters were by far at
their best in the last act where they
were once more at home in an atmosphere of comic emotionalism.
Miss Lehr, whose voice was beautifully adapted to the part of a high
strung mother who fears that her
daughter has spent the night with
the boy next door acquitted herself
admirably, while Jeannette Sauters
as the innocent and naive sub-deb,
was superb. Here, for once the real
tempo of the play was reached with
even the portly Mr. Smith (R. Reardon Fusselbaugh) catching his cues
with alacrity.
Mr. Smith's big moment was
really in the first act when in explaining to his wife how to edu-

father bird . . ." and then, encountering difficulty, turns biblical with
an account of Noah's Ark. Otherwise, there seemed an artificiality
in the relationship of ruliette to her
mother, which may have arisen
either from faulty dialogue, or Miss
Lehr's rather exaggerated facial expression and loud voice, which spoke
of training on a larger stage, and
was not particularly suited to a little theatre.
The play itself, dealing with the
very delicate problem of educating
a rather too innocent and sheltered
ingenue to sex and its mysteries, is
climaxed by a scene in which the
parents of little Janey Smith fear
that she has received the practical
education before the theoretical. In
reality, she was only ensconced on
the sofa downstairs, dreaming a
very Freudian dream, in which her
father is Napoleon; her mother Josephine ;. her friend and lover Chateaubriand ; and she Juliette, the
fairest mistress in France. The action is excellently conceived and organized .. .and there is much clever
and amusing dialogue.

Subs Enter Game

In the second period Lang,
Grochmal and Don Kelly scored
three additional goals to literally
"sew up" the contest. At this juncture Coach Van Orman sent in his
capable lot of reserves to finish the
game. Hopkins made only one tally
in the third quarter, Reid obtaining
it when Reinhold left the goal open
to check another man.
The Shoremen succeeded in ringing up two counters in the final period, but only one of these was scored
by a Washington player, Chambers
netting a tally on an open shot. The
other goal was involuntarily batted
in by Moke Merriken, Hopkins captain, who was trying to break up an
opposing pass. Grochmal and Robinson put two more in for Hopkins
to end the contest.
Unfavorable

Comment

,

Comment upon the style of game
played under the new regulations
was in main part unfavorable.
Coach Van Orman after viewing his
charges in action expressed the opinion that the playing field which has
been shortened 30 yards was too
congested even though the teams
have been cut to ten men. The entire coaching staff is confident that
the game will revert to its original
rules next season.
For its game with Hopkins this
Saturday the Varsity Club has
taken on added strength. The Blue
Jay alumni team expects to be able
to place such oldtimers as Bill Logan, Johnny Lang, Ray Finn, Bill
Keegan and Syd and Max Cone on
the field. Aided by the service of
Corner Brownlee, Gard Mallonee,
Norm Robinson, Frank Cone, and
Frank Dotterweich, the team has already participated in several contests and should be in good shape
for Hopkins.

That's a very simple question to answer.
The stem in a tobacco leaf, like the stem
in most other plants, is "woody". It hasn't
any of the flavor or the aroma that you
want when you smoke. And it doesn't
burn right.
So after tobacco has been properly aged,
one of the first things to do is to remove
the stems.
But what has this to do with your enjoyment of Chesterfield cigarettes? Just this.
It means that we start right when we make
Chesterfield—the right kind of leaf with
the stem removed, the right manufacture
— everything that science knows that can
make CHESTERFIELD a milder cigarette, a
cigarette that tastes better.

DeMolays Conclude
Season With Dance
Officially ending the social activities of the club for this year, the
DeMolays held their last dance of
the year at Levering Hall Saturday.
The Forest Inn orchestra furnished
the music to which the members and
their friends danced. There was a
good turnout and the dance was
proclaimed a success both financially
and socially.
The club has disregarded its supper group and substituted a luncheon group meeting twice monthly on
Fridays at twelve o'clock in Levering Hall.

S. A. C. RULES provide that no activity election is valid unless either the
S. A. C. president or secretary is present.
This implies that the visiting official
knows the rules, is sure of his ground,
is wide awake to all ulterior motives, and
is forceful enough to maintain order. It
was in this role that Squire, as Secretary-Treasurer of the S. A. C., attended
the Band election.
Witness the result: He makes an entirely unfounded ruling to the effect that
proxies are not acceptable by the Council, and thus permits a nominee who was
not elected to take the major office; he
allows the professional director of the
Band to preside at the meeting, a function which belongs exclusively to the
ranking student in the Band. All of
which makes a very unsavory affair of
an otherwise peaceful meeting.

to hold banquets instead of dances during their annual fracas-week is disappointing because it lacks foresight. The

present obstacles which will be encountered. And if they go in the hole,—well,

A treat of an unusual nature is being
offered to Baltimore music lovers at The
Maryland Theatre next week, when The
French-Italian Opera Company, under
the direction of George De Feo, opens
Monday evening for a six-day run.
Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday evenings will witness the performances of
Rigoletto, Faust, and La Bohenze, respectively, while the Wednesday matinee will
be devoted to a presentation of the ever
lovely Barber of Seville.
Lucia de Lamernzoor, Carmen and
Tosca will appear on the last three evenings of the week; the famous twins,
Cavalleria, Rusticana and Pagliacci, being
jointly featured for the matinee on Saturday.
A group of ninety, including a complete
symphony orchestra, a select chorus and
a ballet, comprises this company, the coming of which should prove a real delight
to opera lovers.

Marking their first personal appearance
in this city in over five years, Fred Waring and his Pennsylvanians are the feature attraction on the stage of the Hippodrome this week.
Grand Slam, a witty society drama,
starring pretty Loretta Young and the
inimitable Paul Lukas, completes a fine
bill.
Calvalcade Returns
Several weeks ago we wrote in glowing terms of the flowing and dramatic
grandeur of that epic picture—Cavalcade.
To add more would be to subject a great
masterpiece to cheap bally. Sufficient to
say that this stirring picturization of the
history of a mighty empire has returned
for a weeks' engagement at the New.
You really shouldn't miss it.
Tomorrow evening at the Guild Theatre the brilliant Gilbert and Sullivan stage
success, The Gondoliers, will open for a
run which will extend throughout Easter
week.
The Vagabonds, too, should attract the
interest of many during the course of the
next few days. Fresh from the pen of
Donald Kirkley, dramatic critic of The
Sun, the Eastern Shore play, Peace 0fficer, will hold the boards there for the
coming week.
All of which brings up to the end of
this column and one step removed from
a big surprise. It's coming -next week,
and it's coming here. Are you waitin'?

The Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
Of the two copies of the "Life
and Letters of Thomas Henry
Huxley", in two volumes, once
owned by the University, there remains now a single volume, II. On
the (confessedly faint) hope that
my words may come to the attention of the thieves in question and
bring penitence—and restitution—
I make this appeal.
Huxley ought to mean much to
Hopkins men; he presided over the
University's birth; he was grandfather of Julian and Aldous Huxley; he is the idol of Mr. Mencken.

in a like degree of inspiring students of literature and of science.
I wish the thieves who stole his
record could suffer the crucifixion
they deserve, but I fear there is

Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
Dear Sir:
In a current issue, you carry correspondence to the effect that one
Joseph Gore and myself were cast
in dishonor from a Cumberland
dance emporium. This is malicious
gossip.
In the first place, it wasn't a
dance hall. It was a church. In the
second place, the disturbance was
entirely instigated by Mr. Gore,
who attempted to applaud the officiating divine by banging empty
pop bottles against the pews. My
(Continued on Col. 3, Below)

shop, was awarded a national prize
at its premiere in St. Louis is not
apparent perhaps until the curtain
has rung on the second act. Then
in recovering from a violent and
lengthy spasm of guffaws, from
which even a painfully slow execution did not much detract, one is
thoroughly inclined to agree with
the judges, feeling however, that
the Playshop did not make the best
of the opportunities in this hysterical satire.
Primarily because it could not
keep up the allegro tempo in which
the play was written, and secondly
because the actors seemed too much
impressed by the fact that they were
a Napoleon, or a Juliette, to really
allow full play to the burlesque intended, the comedy of the second
act lost in quality.
It made up for this, however, in
cleverness of line and action.
And Birds

All characters were by far at
their best in the last act where they
were once more at home in an atmosphere of comic emotionalism.
Miss Lehr, whose voice was beautifully adapted to the part of a high
strung mother who fears that her
daughter has spent the night with
the boy next door acquitted herself
admirably, while Jeannette Sauters
as the innocent and naive sub-deb,
was superb. Here, for once the real
tempo of the play was reached with
even the portly Mr. Smith (R. Reardon Fusselbaugh) catching his cues
with alacrity.
Mr. Smith's big moment was
really in the first act when in explaining to his wife how to edu-

father bird . . ." and then, encountering difficulty, turns biblical with
an account of Noah's Ark. Otherwise, there seemed an artificiality
in the relationship of ruliette to her
mother, which may have arisen
either from faulty dialogue, or Miss
Lehr's rather exaggerated facial expression and loud voice, which spoke
of training on a larger stage, and
was not particularly suited to a little theatre.
The play itself, dealing with the
very delicate problem of educating
a rather too innocent and sheltered
ingenue to sex and its mysteries, is
climaxed by a scene in which the
parents of little Janey Smith fear
that she has received the practical
education before the theoretical. In
reality, she was only ensconced on
the sofa downstairs, dreaming a
very Freudian dream, in which her
father is Napoleon; her mother Josephine ;. her friend and lover Chateaubriand ; and she Juliette, the
fairest mistress in France. The action is excellently conceived and organized .. .and there is much clever
and amusing dialogue.

opposing pass. Grochmal and Robinson put two more in for Hopkins
to end the contest.

Comment upon the style of game
played under the new regulations
was in main part unfavorable.
Coach Van Orman after viewing his
charges in action expressed the opinion that the playing field which has
been shortened 30 yards was too
congested even though the teams
have been cut to ten men. The entire coaching staff is confident that
the game will revert to its original
rules next season.

Saturday the Varsity Club has
taken on added strength. The Blue
Jay alumni team expects to be able
to place such oldtimers as Bill Logan, Johnny Lang, Ray Finn, Bill
Keegan and Syd and Max Cone on
the field. Aided by the service of
Corner Brownlee, Gard Mallonee,
Norm Robinson, Frank Cone, and
Frank Dotterweich, the team has already participated in several contests and should be in good shape
for Hopkins.

The stem in a tobacco leaf, like the stem

want when you smoke. And it doesn't
burn right.
So after tobacco has been properly aged,
one of the first things to do is to remove
the stems.
